A synoptic low pressure system brought snow to central lower Michigan and freezing rain to southern lower Michigan. Storm total snowfall reached six inches across much of central Michigan and freezing rain resulted in significant ice accumulations of 0.3 to 0.5.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of deep moisture and slow movement of storms resulted in flash flooding in some parts of extreme southwestern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of water was reported over pokagan highway southwest of Cassopolis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough moved across Michigan producing storms that layed out several outflow boundaries that worked across far southern Lower Michigan. These boundaries interacted with a high CAPE/low shear environment to set the stage for pulse thunderstorms. Several wet microbursts developed and produced areas of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down onto power lines 6 miles north of Coldwater. Dime size hail was also reported in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough moved across Michigan producing storms that layed out several outflow boundaries that worked across far southern Lower Michigan. These boundaries interacted with a high CAPE/low shear environment to set the stage for pulse thunderstorms. Several wet microbursts developed and produced areas of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered reports of trees down in and around the Hillsdale area as well as western parts of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a prefrontal outflow boundary drapped across northern Indiana and a MCV from overnight convection across Nebraska the night before provided the focus for convection to develop. In addition, unstable conditions develop during the late morning and early afternoon with SBCAPES of 1500 to 2500 j/kg. Storms began to develop on this boundary during the mid afternoon hours and rapidly became severe across Indiana. A line of storms associated with the MCV and an approaching trough moved across the northern part of Indiana and into extreme southern Michigan. This line evolved into several small bowing segments which produced numerous reports of damaging winds, especially across parts of St Joseph county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey was performed by NWS personnel of the area between Three Rivers and Mendon, including Fishers Lake. Damage was observed at the Three Rivers Muncipal Airport and at an adjacent residence to the airport. A hangar door was blown open at the airport, with 2 large tree trunks falling onto parked vehicles at a private residence. One of the vehicles had pulled into the driveway due to poor visbility, and before the driver could exit, the tree trunk fell onto the roof of the car, causing minor head injury to the driver. The Three Rivers AWOS (KHAI) recorded a 68 mph wind gust at 548 pm EDT. As the survey progressed along M-60 to some of the back roads, more extensive damage began to be encountered. A barn was found destroyed by a combination of the strong winds and a small shed being picked up and thrown into the barn. An adjacent barn also suffered moderate damage from the wind. Numerous trees limbs were snapped in the yard, as well as the chimney of the 2 story residence being blown over to roof level. Just to the north of this residence a large grove of various hardwood trees suffered extensive damage with many trees being uprooted or snapped. The sandy soil in the area reduced the resistance of the roots somewhat.  A residence as well as a barn suffered only minor damage despite the estimated 90 to 95 mph winds. KIWX 88D Base velocity data showed a couplet with 82 kt (94 mph) outbound winds in this general area. Damage continued northeast towards Mendon where trees continued to be damaged as well as 2 barns. |With the strength of the winds, it is possible that a few gust front tornadoes (gustnadoes) may have developed and helped locally focus some of the damage, but by far the strength of the straight line winds was more significant then the potential winds of any gustnadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large trees were reported blown down in Litchfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air surged into Northern Michigan, bringing gusty winds and light accumulations of lake effect snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blustery winds gusting off of Lake Michigan brought down a few trees and power lines.  Motorists in four vehicles were trapped in their cars for nearly two hours, when power lines came down across M-22 south of Leland (just south of M-204).  A summer home on the west shore of Lake Leelanau was destroyed by a fire ignited by downed power lines (indirect damage).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold west-southwest winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow to the tip of Northern Lower Michigan.  An initial burst of snow brought 4 to 5 inches to parts of Charlevoix and Emmet Counties during the daylight hours of the 23rd.  There was a lull that night, before another burst dropped around 6 inches of snow from Stutsmanville to just north of Pellston in central Emmet County.

Heavy lake effect snow produced storm total snowfall of 9 to as much as 17 inches across the lakeshore counties of extreme western lower Michigan and also into Kalamazoo county. The most snow was reported across Allegan and Van Buren counties where 15 to 17 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As much as 15 inches of snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow resulted in 7 to 12 inches of total snowfall across portions of far southwest lower Michigan. The highest snowfall total came from Van Buren county where portions of that county received a foot of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to ten inches of lake effect snow was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to twelve inches of lake effect snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were two reports of non thunderstorm high wind gusts near the Lake Michigan shoreline.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A non thunderstorm wind gust reaching 58 mph was recorded at Little Sable Point on the Lake Michigan shoreline.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A synoptic low pressure system brought snow to central lower Michigan and freezing rain to southern lower Michigan. Storm total snowfall reached six inches across much of central Michigan and freezing rain resulted in significant ice accumulations of 0.3 to 0.5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of six inches was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant snow event occurred across much of lower Michigan, with snowfall totals generally ranging anywhere from around four to ten inches.  The heaviest snowfall reports were received from the I-94 corridor, where around ten inches of snow fell at many locations.  Around six to eight inches of snow fell in many spots near the I-96 corridor, and slightly lower snowfall amounts of four to six inches were reported northwest of Grand Rapids.

A narrow line of rain with embedded thunderstorms just ahead of an arctic cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 50 to 78 mph.  This resulted in widespread power outages and reports of wind damage across central and southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 knot wind gust was measured at the Kalamazoo airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 56 knot wind gust was estimated by a trained spotter in Barry county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light north-northeast winds off of Lake Michigan brought localized heavy lake effect to parts of Northwest Lower Michigan.  A band that extended down Grand Traverse Bay dumped six inches of snow on Traverse City.

A potent upper level disturbance lifted across Michigan on the 28th, bringing a relatively short period of heavy snow.  Accumulations of five to six inches were common across almost all of Northern Michigan, falling in just six hours.  Cross Village had the most accumulation with just short of nine inches, while Gaylord, Suttons Bay, McKinley, and Moran were around eight inches.

An Alberta clipper moved quickly southeast across the Great Lakes, leaving a swath of 3 to 5 of snow in most areas. Isolated locations received from 5 to 7 inches in some of the heavier bands across parts of extreme southern Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Cassopolis reported 6.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold northwest winds produced lake effect snow in the usual snowbelts of Northern Michigan.  The Elmira area picked up 6 inches of snow, in a Lake Michigan snowband that peaked on the morning of the 9th.  That night, the focus shifted northward, when a Lake Superior snowband dumped 13 inches of snow on Brimley and Bay Mills.

Cold northwest winds produced lake effect snow in the usual snowbelts of Northern Michigan.  The Elmira area picked up 6 inches of snow, in a Lake Michigan snowband that peaked on the morning of the 9th.  That night, the focus shifted northward, when a Lake Superior snowband dumped 13 inches of snow on Brimley and Bay Mills.

A strong cold front brought accumulating snow in the early morning hours of the 19th.  Lake effect snow developed behind the front, and the most significant banding occurred on Lake Superior.  A narrow area, from Brimley to Pickford, picked up 8 to 10 inches of snow.

Unseasonable warm and moist air interacted with a powerful cold front to bring several small lines of thunderstorms. While the majority of the stronger winds were not able to reach the ground, some wind gusts in the 60 to over 70 mph range were noted across parts of far southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials reported numerous trees and power lines down across the county.

Weak winds in the morning of the 24th allowed a lake-induced mesovortex to form on Northern Lake Michigan.  An increase in northwest winds during the day eventually brought the vortex onshore, producing locally heavy snow in Leelanau County.  Leland and Lake Leelanau both picked up 6 to 7 inches of snow.

Cold northerly winds brought lake effect snow to parts of Northwest Lower Michigan. Six to ten inches of snow fell in East Jordan, Mancelona, and Kalkaska.  The biggest accumulation, ten inches, fell just southeast of Mancelona.

A trough of low pressure dropped southward across Lake Superior, along with a band of heavy snow. Northwest winds behind the trough resulted in lake effect snow. Paradise picked up 8 to 10 inches of snow, while Tahquamenon Falls had 15 inches.

Heavy snow moved into southern lower Michigan during the early evening hours of New Year's Eve, impacting New Year's travel plans by creating very hazardous travel conditions in heavy snow and snow covered roads.  Many locations across southern Michigan reported total snowfall of 7 to 10 inches, with as much as 11.5 inches reported three miles south southeast of Jackson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This heavy snow event continued into the early morning hours on New Year's Day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This heavy snow event continued into the early morning hours on New Year's Day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front combined with west southwest winds along and just ahead of it to promote development of lake effect snow primarily west of US-131. The highest snowfall report came from Jenison in eastern Ottawa county where ten inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across much of Ottawa county and a total of ten inches of snow was reported in Jenison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front combined with west southwest winds along and just ahead of it to promote development of lake effect snow primarily west of US-131. The highest snowfall report came from Jenison in eastern Ottawa county where ten inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across most of Kent county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front combined with west southwest winds along and just ahead of it to promote development of lake effect snow primarily west of US-131. The highest snowfall report came from Jenison in eastern Ottawa county where ten inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across most of Allegan county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow occurred across Allegan and Van Buren counties with maximum snowfall of 7 inches for this event reported in South Haven.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Holland and Bloomingdale reported six inches of lake effect snow with this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow occurred across Allegan and Van Buren counties with maximum snowfall of 7 inches for this event reported in South Haven.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Haven reported seven inches of lake effect snow with this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of ten inches was reported across portions of Lake county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of ten inches was reported across portions of Newaygo county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blustery winds behind a cold front downed trees in Gladwin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees downed, blocking roads 5 miles southeast of Beaverton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 12 inches was reported across portions of Osceola county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 12 inches was reported across portions of Mecosta county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 12 inches was reported across portions of Isabella county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous low pressure system produced nine to twelve inch snow accumulations across much of central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 9 inches was reported across portions of Montcalm county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold northwest winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow to Northwest Lower Michigan.  Suttons Bay picked up 8 to 10 inches of snow.

A clipper system brought snow to the region.  Lake Michigan enhanced the snowfall, both ahead of the system (with west-southwest winds), and behind (with northwest winds).  In both wind regimes, wind speeds were light, keeping the heavier snow fairly close to the coastline.  Suttons Bay picked up 7 inches of snow, while Charlevoix and Central Lake both had around 6 inches.
Rapid snowmelt upstream resulted in considerable flooding in Arenac County.  Ice cover on rivers and streams, and on Saginaw Bay downstream, slowed runoff and contributed to flooding problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rifle River near Sterling crested at 9.6 feet, above the estimated flood stage of 8 feet.  In Clayton Township, water encroached on North and Main Roads, and near Town Line and Dobler Roads.  In Standish Township, high water impacted Foco and Palmer Roads, and Arenac State Road just north of Worth Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over an inch of rain fell on East Central Lower Michigan in the early morning hours of the 22nd.  Snowmelt upstream contributed to runoff, producing flooding in parts of Arenac County.  Ice jams on the Rifle and Au Gres Rivers may have contributed to the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rifle River near Sterling crested early on the morning of the 22nd at around 9.5 feet, above the estimated flood stage of 8 feet.  The Au Gres River also rose out of its banks.  A number of road closures resulted across the county, including parts of Santiago Road, Twining Road, Mackinaw Road, Hammel Beach Road, Court Street, Thaut Road, and Bessinger Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog formed in Marquette and Baraga counties on the morning of the 3rd and then continued into the afternoon hours before dissipating.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog formed in Marquette and Baraga counties on the morning of the 3rd and then continued into the afternoon hours before dissipating.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced large hail in far Northern Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds estimated between 35 and 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One last burst of lake effect snow dumped 6 to 8 inches of accumulation on western and central Kalkaska County on the night of the 7th.
Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours.  A pair of storms in Alpena County reached severe levels.
Gusty onshore winds contributed to rip current development on Lake Michigan beaches of Northwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 15 year old boy from a downstate Michigan community, drowned as a result of rip currents at 5th Avenue Beach in the city of Manistee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dry conditions contributed to the development of a significant wildfire in Iosco County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fast-developing wildfire burned between 500 and 600 acres in Wilber Township, nine miles northwest of Tawas City.  Stands of jack pine were the primary fuel for the fire.  A hundred people were evacuated from the area, and three homes were damaged.  The fire was fully contained by late that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance ignited a band of showers and embedded thunderstorms, which moved into Northern Michigan from the southwest.  A few storms in the band produced marginally large hail.
An upper level disturbance ignited a band of showers and embedded thunderstorms, which moved into Northern Michigan from the southwest.  A few storms in the band produced marginally large hail.
Thunderstorms ignited off of lake breezes as they pushed inland.  A number of storms produced large hail, especially in Northeast Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed onto power lines, near M-65 about a mile south of MacDonald Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a humid airmass, well ahead of a cold front moving south from Canada.  One storm in Eastern Upper Michigan reached severe levels.

A line of thunderstorms, well ahead of a cold front, advanced out of Wisconsin and across Lake Michigan.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.  Showers along the front itself managed to produce a waterspout on Torch Lake.

A line of thunderstorms, well ahead of a cold front, advanced out of Wisconsin and across Lake Michigan.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.  Showers along the front itself managed to produce a waterspout on Torch Lake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout, associated with some showers, came onshore as a weak tornado near the south end of Torch Lake.  The waterspout tore up some docks, and downed a few tree limbs.  It was estimated as a low-end EF0 tornado, with winds of around 65 mph.  Note that it is not known where the waterspout initially touched down, as the waterspout was not observed until it was already moving onshore.  The tornado dissipated almost immediately upon coming onshore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms, well ahead of a cold front, advanced out of Wisconsin and across Lake Michigan.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.  Showers along the front itself managed to produce a waterspout on Torch Lake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms, well ahead of a cold front, advanced out of Wisconsin and across Lake Michigan.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.  Showers along the front itself managed to produce a waterspout on Torch Lake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed near Cinder Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms, well ahead of a cold front, advanced out of Wisconsin and across Lake Michigan.  The line produced a few spots of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.  Showers along the front itself managed to produce a waterspout on Torch Lake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed.  One building was damaged by a falling tree, and a car on South Otsego Avenue near the library was also struck and damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours.  A pair of storms in Alpena County reached severe levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail fell at Thunder Bay Golf Club.  In addition, 40 mph wind gusts downed small tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed behind a synoptic low pressure system which moved through our area on March first.  Twelve to as much as fifteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan, Ottawa, and western Kent counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to eleven inches of snow was reported across portions of Oceana county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed behind a synoptic low pressure system which moved through our area on March first.  Twelve to as much as fifteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan, Ottawa, and western Kent counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to twelve inches of snow was reported across portions of Mecosta county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed behind a synoptic low pressure system which moved through our area on March first.  Twelve to as much as fifteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan, Ottawa, and western Kent counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to fifteen inches of snow was reported across portions of Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed behind a synoptic low pressure system which moved through our area on March first.  Twelve to as much as fifteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan, Ottawa, and western Kent counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to fifteen inches of snow was reported across portions of Allegan county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southwest flow lake effect snow event developed in advance of an upper level system which moved into the area.  There was a narrow band of four to seven inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to seven inches of snow was reported across portions of Clare county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southwest flow lake effect snow event developed in advance of an upper level system which moved into the area.  There was a narrow band of four to seven inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to six inches of snow was reported across portions of Newaygo county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced three quarters inch hail in Barry county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three quarters inch diameter hail was reported by the public in Delton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in severe thunderstorm wind gusts across portions of Allegan and Van Buren counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported that numerous trees were blown down by a severe thunderstorm in Hamilton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm resulted in severe thunderstorm wind gusts across portions of Allegan and Van Buren counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported that numerous trees were blown down by severe thunderstorm wind gusts in South Haven and Bangor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms over Clare county produced several reports of three quarters to seven eighths inch diameter hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three quarters inch diameter hail was reported by law enforcement four miles northwest of Lake and two miles north of Farwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms over Clare county produced several reports of three quarters to seven eighths inch diameter hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven eighths inch diameter hail was reported by a trained spotter seven miles southwest of Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance ignited a band of showers and embedded thunderstorms, which moved into Northern Michigan from the southwest.  A few storms in the band produced marginally large hail.

In both wind regimes, wind speeds were light, keeping the heavier snow fairly close to the coastline. A low pressure trough moving slowly across the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate snow to portions of western Upper Michigan on the 25th and 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer eleven miles west-southwest of Watersmeet measured 6.5 inches of total snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred in Alger and northern Schoolcraft counties from the evening of the 30th continuing into the morning of December 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 13 miles south of Grand Marais measured 13 inches of snow in a 24-hour period ending on the morning of December 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers deposited 10 inches or more of snow in 24 hours over portions of Alger and northern Schoolcraft counties ending on the morning of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 13 miles south of Grand Marais measured 13 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow showers deposited 10 inches or more of snow in 24 hours over portions of Alger and northern Schoolcraft counties ending on the morning of the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported ten inches of snow in 24 hours for a period ending on the morning of the 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system moving across the region enhanced lake effect snowfall across portions of Marquette County from the 4th into the morning of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 10.5 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking through Upper Michigan brought strong wind and near-blizzard conditions to portions of Delta County on the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds in excess of 40 mph at times downed power lines and knocked out elctricity to 96 customers in Escanaba.  Near-blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow also contributed to several accidents in Delta County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving slowly across the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate snow to portions of western Upper Michigan on the 25th and 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Watton observer reported inch per hour snowfall rates at times while measuring eight inches of total snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Perfect conditions came together to cause an unusual deposition of heavy frost to freeze on roads. Temperatures around 30 degrees led to a dangerous buildup of black ice, especially on bridges, overpasses, and in low lying rural areas. Numerous accidents were reported during the morning commute.

Winds gusted up to 50 mph behind a cold front.  With trees fully leafed out, some tree damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power pole was knocked over 12 miles south of Paradise, starting a fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted up to 50 mph behind a cold front.  With trees fully leafed out, some tree damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines downed from Bear Lake to the southern county line.  City of Manistee fire station measured a 48 mph gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lowland flooding resulted from 3 to 4 inches of rain that fell on June 2nd and 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sterling Road was closed between Grove Street and US-23, due to substantial soil erosion in the roadbed.  Water also inundated part of US-23 near Foco Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of severe thunderstorms developed in Northwest Lower Michigan.  Only one report of severe hail was received, as the storms affected mainly rural, forested areas in Benzie, Manistee, and Wexford Counties.
A few thunderstorms developed on a sticky afternoon.  One storm in Alcona County produced wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were downed in Mikado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed during the warmest part of the day, with lake breezes serving as the initial trigger.  Some storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed during the warmest part of the day, with lake breezes serving as the initial trigger.  Some storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees downed west through northwest of Manton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed during the warmest part of the day, with lake breezes serving as the initial trigger.  Some storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree downed on Blue Lake Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed during the warmest part of the day, with lake breezes serving as the initial trigger.  Some storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree downed onto utility lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked from Lake Superior to James Bay. The associated strong cold front swept toward Lower Michigan on the late afternoon of July 10th. Southwesterly flow ahead of the front allowed a warm and moist unstable atmosphere to develop. Numerous pulse severe thunderstorms produced many reports of damaging wind gusts along and north of the I-69 corridor. There were no reports of hail. The most significant damage occurred in Fort Gratiot, where a strong thunderstorm downburst created straight line wind damage one mile wide covering two square miles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported several large tree branches down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported tree branches 10 inches in diameter down and estimated the wind gusts at 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced wind damage and large hail over south central portions of Upper Michigan on the evening of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines down along County Road 607 and near Highway M-95 in Breitung Township.  A home along County Road 607 sustained damage when a tree fell on it.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Gogebic and Marquette counties during the early morning hours of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail lasted 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Gogebic and Marquette counties during the early morning hours of the 28th.
Severe thunderstorms produced wind damage and large hail over south central portions of Upper Michigan on the evening of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree downed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down across the city...amount and sizes unknown.  Widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record setting heat led to an isolated thunderstorm. A barn in Shiawassee Township was destroyed when lightning struck it and set it on fire. Farm equipment and bales of hay were burned in the blaze. Total monetary damage caused by the lightning was estimated at roughly $25K.

An area of thunderstorms moved across Northern Michigan during the morning hours.  A man in Cheboygan County, while standing in his garage watching the storm, was jolted and shaken up by a lightning strike in his immediate vicinity.  He sought medical treatment later in the day.
A cold front brought showers and a few thunderstorms to Northern Michigan.  One storm produced nickel sized hail in Wexford County.

Scattered thunderstorms tracked across Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 14th ahead and along a warm frontal passage. A few of these storms produced large hail over Marquette, Alger and Luce counties. |A second round of severe storms developed in the evening coincident with a cold frontal passage. These storms producing large hail and damaging wind over the west half of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to quarter-sized hail.

A few of these storms produced large hail over Marquette, Alger and Luce counties. |A second round of severe storms developed in the evening coincident with a cold frontal passage. These storms producing large hail and damaging wind over the west half of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported by the KSAW tower.  Pea-sized hail also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms tracked across Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 14th ahead and along a warm frontal passage. A few of these storms produced large hail over Marquette, Alger and Luce counties. |A second round of severe storms developed in the evening coincident with a cold frontal passage. These storms producing large hail and damaging wind over the west half of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms ignited off of lake breezes as they pushed inland.  A number of storms produced large hail, especially in Northeast Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two canoers, one male and one female, were struck by lightning while taking shelter under a tree during a thunderstorm.  The woman was knocked unconscious, and both suffered significant burns.  They were transported to a burn center in Flint to recover.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More thunderstorms crossed Northern Michigan on the night of the 14th.  One storm produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous tree limbs were downed.  A slide was blown off of a playset in a backyard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating allowed thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 30th.  A few storms became severe in Northeast Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several poplar trees downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating allowed thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 30th.  A few storms became severe in Northeast Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree downed at a campground, falling onto a camper trailer.  Power lost in part of campground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating allowed thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 30th.  A few storms became severe in Northeast Lower Michigan.

A north-northwest flow in the wake of an upper disturbance brought heavy lake effect snowfall to Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from the 14th through the early morning hours of the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snowfall in 12 hours was reported by an observer in Munising.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure diving down from central Canada brought an Arctic cold front through the Upper Great Lakes on the 27th. Lake effect snow showers which developed in the wake of the cold front lasted into the morning of the 28th and brought heavy accumulation to locations downwind of Lake Superior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 14.2 inches of snowfall in 15 hours at Rockland.  Visibility was reported near zero at times in heavy snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers deposited heavy snowfall in the northwest wind snowbelts of west and north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th through the evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snowfall was observed in 24 hours at Painesdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers deposited heavy snowfall in the northwest wind snowbelts of west and north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th through the evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snowfall was observed in 24 hours at Rockland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers in the wake of an Arctic cold front buried portions of Gogebic...Marquette...Baraga and Alger counties in heavy snow from the afternoon of 14th through the 15th.  Ishpeming, Negaunee, NICE, Powell and Gwinn area schools were all closed on the 15th due to the storm. Slippery highways were also responsible for numerous accidents throughout the area and five reported injuries in Marquette County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 12-hour snowfall amount of 8 inches at Eben Junction and 10 inches in 24 hours. Some minor accidents were reported due to the snow-covered highways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported storm total snowfall of thirteen inches at L'anse and twelve inches at Pelkie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air in the wake of a low pressure trough helped intensify lake effect snow showers over Alger and Schoolcraft Counties on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snowfall was reported in 24 hours by an observer at Smith Lake, located 10 miles north of Manistique along Highway M-94.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds shifting northwest in the wake of a surface trough brought heavy lake effect snowfall downwind of Lake Superior from the 1st continuing into the 4th. A sharp cold front moving through on the 2nd reinforced the Arctic airmass over the region and caused wind chills to plummet to 35 to 40 below zero across portions of Upper Michigan on the 3rd continuing into the morning of the 6th. |Many area schools were closed or delayed on the 5th with a few remaining closed or delayed on the 6th due to the frigid weather. The Iron Mountain Fire Department responded to calls of sprinkler systems bursting, while several residents in Ishpeming reported frozen pipes during the Arctic outbreak.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 24-hour snowfall totals ending on the morning of the 2nd of 14.5 inches at Atlantic Mine and 11 inches at Calumet. Additional observer reports of 24-hour snowfall totals ending on the morning of the 3rd included 17 inches at Chassell, another 14 inches at Atlantic Mine and 11 inches at Painesdale. Gusty west to northwest winds also caused blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibilities through the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system stalled over Upper Michigan and helped focus intense lake-enhanced snow bands into Delta and southern Schoolcraft counties during the overnight of the 29th-30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snowfall was observed in 12 hours at Garden Corners.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported in Seney during the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 2nd.  East winds gusting to 40 mph at times caused occasional whiteout conditions in blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 12-hour snowfall amounts of 9 inches at Munising, Au Train and Grand Marais. Winds near 30 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An EF-3 tornado struck Eaton county and resulted in five injuries but no fatalities.  An EF-1 tornado struck Ingham county but did not produce any injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado struck Ingham county south and east of the city of Lansing.  Maximum winds were estimated at 90 mph.  The track of the tornado was six miles long and 200 to 300 yards wide.  ||The first sign of damage was near the intersections of Waverly and M-99.  Significant damage occurred at the Stonegate mobile home park south of M-99. Many trees were down there and some fell on mobile homes.  The damage path continued northeast toward I-96 across Grovenburg Road. ||More tree damage was found on the north side of I-96 along Haag Road. The damage path continued northeast across Miller Road through neighborhoods where numerous oak trees were blown down, some onto homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An EF-3 tornado struck Eaton county and resulted in five injuries but no fatalities.  An EF-1 tornado struck Ingham county but did not produce any injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS storm survey team determined that an EF-3 (Enhanced-Fujita Tornado Scale Rating) tornado with wind speeds estimated at 140 mph produced the most severe damage along a path from M-50 just north of Kinsel Highway to just west of M-100 and Vermontville Highway near Potterville, Michigan. The storm survey indicated a tornado path which was 200 to 300 yards wide and 6.5 miles long.||Fifteen homes were either destroyed or severely damaged. A roof was blown off a single story home and windward facing walls were blown in. The majority of the roof and garage from this home were not found. A roof was blown off of a two story home and the upper story front walls were blown in. Additional damage included the partial collapse of the upper story of a home, and another house was blown off of the foundation. Two barns were destroyed and another incurred heavy damage just west of Potterville.

East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One-quarter inch of ice accumulation was reported on windshields 5 miles southwest of Iron River.  Also, there were several reports of 5 inches of snow throughout the county during the evening of the 1st.

Grand Marais received another 12 inches of snow for the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 4th.  Gusty west to northwest winds caused blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibilities through the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twelve inches of snowfall was measured in 24 hours four miles south of Ontonagon. Gusty northwest winds also caused some blowing of snow and reduced visibilities.

Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow combined with east winds gusting over 50 mph at times caused near-blizzard conditions and forced the closure of Highway US-2 east of Escanaba from the evening of the 1st into the morning of the 2nd. Schools were closed throughout the area on the 2nd. Observers reported 24-hour snowfall totals of 10 inches at Escanaba and Perkins.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers in the wake of an Arctic cold front buried portions of Gogebic...Marquette...Baraga and Alger counties in heavy snow from the afternoon of 14th through the 15th.  Ishpeming, Negaunee, NICE, Powell and Gwinn area schools were all closed on the 15th due to the storm. Slippery highways were also responsible for numerous accidents throughout the area and five reported injuries in Marquette County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall storm total of 18 inches was observed at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township with eight inches measured in 12 hours from the evening of the 14th through the morning of the 15th. A storm total of 13.5 inches was reported at Gwinn.  Numerous traffic accidents were attributed to the storm, and five people were treated for accident-related injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A foot of snowfall was observed five miles east of Superior Falls and 8-10 inches was reported in Bessemer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms dropped large hail over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail...mostly dime-sized with a few penny size.

Gusty east wind to near 50 mph at times along the Ontonagon shoreline caused near-blizzard conditions during the evening of the 1st. Schools were closed in the Ontonagon area on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure diving down from central Canada brought an Arctic cold front through the Upper Great Lakes on the 27th. Lake effect snow showers which developed in the wake of the cold front lasted into the morning of the 28th and brought heavy accumulation to locations downwind of Lake Superior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snowfall was observed in 24 hours by a spotter five miles north of Shingleton. The Alger County Sheriff reported that numerous cars slid off the highways due to the snowpacked highways and poor visibility...especially along Highway M-28 between Munising and Shingleton. One minor traffic crash occurred near Eben, but no injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure center moving over Lake Superior helped spawn severe thunderstorms over the Dickinson and Marquette counties on the afternoon of the 10th.  Non-thunderstorm wind damage was also reported over Gogebic and Houghton counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eighteen inch diameter tree was blown down near the high school in Calumet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure diving down from central Canada brought an Arctic cold front through the Upper Great Lakes on the 27th. Lake effect snow showers which developed in the wake of the cold front lasted into the morning of the 28th and brought heavy accumulation to locations downwind of Lake Superior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter at Herman measured 12 inches of snow in 12 hours and 18 inches of snow in 24 hours.

Lake effect snow showers which developed in the wake of the cold front lasted into the morning of the 28th and brought heavy accumulation to locations downwind of Lake Superior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine inches of snowfall was observed in 12 hours by a NWS employee in Ishpeming.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure diving down from central Canada brought an Arctic cold front through the Upper Great Lakes on the 27th. Lake effect snow showers which developed in the wake of the cold front lasted into the morning of the 28th and brought heavy accumulation to locations downwind of Lake Superior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 12.5 inches of snowfall in less than 24 hours at Ironwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers deposited heavy snowfall in the northwest wind snowbelts of west and north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th through the evening of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twelve inches of snow was reported in 24 hours by an observer just south of Shingleton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure center moving over Lake Superior helped spawn severe thunderstorms over the Dickinson and Marquette counties on the afternoon of the 10th.  Non-thunderstorm wind damage was also reported over Gogebic and Houghton counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eight inch diameter poplar tree was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 15 inches of snowfall at Nisula along Highway M-38.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from the afternoon of the 1st into the morning of the 2nd included fifteen inches at Atlantic Mine, twelve inches at Painesdale and eight inches at Houghton.  There were numerous reports of winds gusts near 50 mph, near-zero visibility, and thunder and lightning with heavy snow.  Many streets, schools and businesses were closed on the 2nd, including Michigan Tech University and the Houghton County courthouse.

Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall reports from the afternoon of the 1st into the morning of the 2nd included seven inches at both Mohawk and Phoenix.  The Mohawk observer reported frequent wind gusts of 35 mph or higher along with near-zero visibility and snow drifts of three to four feet high.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported 8 to 10 inches of snowfall in Hermansville from the 1st through the morning of the 2nd.  Sleet mixing with snow caused numerous minor accidents in Menominee. Wind gusts over 40 mph also downed billboard signs and caused power outages in Menominee on the evening of the 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air in the wake of a low pressure trough helped intensify lake effect snow showers over Alger and Schoolcraft Counties on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snowfall was reported in 24 hours over rural northern Schoolcraft County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air in the wake of a low pressure trough helped intensify lake effect snow showers over Alger and Schoolcraft Counties on the 17th and 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snowfall was reported in 24 hours by an observer at Au Train.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms over south central lower Michigan produced a couple of reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down at Round Lake road and Looking Glass river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms over south central lower Michigan produced a couple of reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down one mile north of Webberville.  A house was also damaged at the intersection of Allen and Morrice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across portions of central lower Michigan produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven eighths inch diameter hail was reported by local media in Brohman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across portions of central lower Michigan produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was blown down in Paris and another was blown down in Big Rapids.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across portions of central lower Michigan produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported at Clare and seven eighths inch diameter hail was reported at Farwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across portions of central lower Michigan produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three trees were blown down and one fell on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of wind damage were received from portions of Montcalm and Isabella counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and limbs were blown down two to three miles northwest of Stanton.  A tin roof was also ripped off of a barn by the wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of wind damage were received from portions of Montcalm and Isabella counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts also blew a shed off of it's foundation and a camper was blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several damaging wind gusts across portions of Clinton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down in Ovid.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High Winds not related to thunderstorms brought down several trees and power lines and also caused damage to some area buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Non convective thunderstorm wind gusts brought down several trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across Mason county brought down several trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were blown down across western portions of Mason county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds caused tree damage in Marquette on the evening of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds broke a 12-inch diameter tree limb off near the corner of Pine Street and Lakeshore Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds and high waves on Lake Independence resulted in the drowning deaths of two elderly men on the evening of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two elderly men, aged 71 and 72, drowned on the evening of the 9th after their fishing boat capsized on Lake Independence. High winds reportedly whipped up waves in the 4 to 6 feet range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several damaging wind gusts across portions of Clinton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and tree limbs were blown down in and just north northwest of Lansing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms across Mason county brought down several trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down in portions of Mason county including one to three miles west of Freesoil, in Scottville and in Ludington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind gusts brought down several trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dozen trees and several power lines were blown down in St. John's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind gusts and hail occurred across portions of far southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roof damage was incurred to a barn six miles northwest of Mason due to a severe thunderstorm wind gust and a large tree limb was blown down in South Lansing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind gusts and hail occurred across portions of far southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported three quarters inch hail in Mattawan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind gusts and hail occurred across portions of far southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down five miles west of Portage, in Schoolcraft and one mile east of Vicksburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system stalled over Upper Michigan and helped focus intense lake-enhanced snow bands into Delta and southern Schoolcraft counties during the overnight of the 29th-30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen inches of snowfall in 12 hours was reported at Cooks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several damaging wind gusts across portions of Clinton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down along Sherwood Road two miles north of Williamston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several damaging wind gusts across portions of Clinton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A drowning in Lake Michigan was most likely caused by rip currents near Douglas and Saugatuck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure center moving over Lake Superior helped spawn severe thunderstorms over the Dickinson and Marquette counties on the afternoon of the 10th.  Non-thunderstorm wind damage was also reported over Gogebic and Houghton counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power was knocked out in Ironwood.  Large branches were blown down near Ironwood and Bessemer.  Power lines were blown down in Wakefield.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of fourteen inches was observed at Channing.  Dickinson County law enforcement agencies reported a few minor accidents throughout the area. Most area schools were closed on the 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts included 23 inches at Bessemer, 19 inches at Ironwood, 17 inches at Marenisco and 13 inches at Watersmeet. Schools were closed throughout the Gogebic Range on the 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The sheriff's department reported 10 inches of snowfall in 3 hours five miles west of Seney.  Visibility was near zero in heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow produced storm total snowfall of 9 to as much as 17 inches across the lakeshore counties of extreme western lower Michigan and also into Kalamazoo county. The most snow was reported across Allegan and Van Buren counties where 15 to 17 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen inches of snow was reported.

A strong cold front moved across Upper Michigan on the 5th producing lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over west and north central Upper Michigan. Gusty north winds in excess of 50 mph were also reported at several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Champion and Negaunee measured ten to twelve inches of snow in 24 hours. Considerable blowing and drifting of snow was also observed as winds gusted in excess of 40 mph at some locations. The combination of heavy snow and strong wind gusts of 45 to 50 mph downed trees and caused power outages in Marquette. Numerous accidents were attributed to slippery roadways and poor visibility. In addition, most area schools were closed on the 6th due to the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter at Paint Lake, south of Kenton, reported a storm total snowfall of 12 inches.

Drought conditions (severe, or D2), which carried over from August, eased thanks to wet weather early in the month.  Charlevoix County was removed from severe drought when around an inch of rain fell from the 3rd into the 4th.

Drought conditions (severe, or D2) carried over from August in Eastern Upper Michigan and far Northern Lower Michigan.  Several rain events eased the drought by mid-month.  The area received half an inch to an inch of rain on September 3-4, again on the 7th, and again on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small cluster of thunderstorms produced severe weather in Leelanau County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a fire, which destroyed a three-car garage and a boat that was inside, and melted vinyl siding on an adjacent home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small line of thunderstorms produced wind damage in central Chippewa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A shed was damaged, and several large tree limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked from Arkansas to the Upper Ohio Valley and spread heavy snow north into Michigan. This Valentine's snowstorm marked the season's first snowfall over 2 inches for much of the affected area. Northeasterly winds frequently gusted to 30 MPH and created extensive blowing and drifting snow. In addition, temperatures were in the single digits with wind chill values around 15 below zero. The snow began Tuesday afternoon of the 13th and became heavy at times through the evening and into the early morning hours of the 14th. The winds made it extremely difficult to measure the snow, but trained spotters estimated 6 to 9 inches of snow fell on areas along and east of a line from Port Huron to Adrian. Snow drifts from 3 to 5 feet were reported across this same area. A number of county roads were impassable, prompting officials to close some roads. Several motorists had to be rescued when their vehicles became stuck in snow drifts in Lenawee County. Although lesser amounts of snow (3 to 5 inches) fell across Livingston, Genesee, and Lapeer Counties, numerous accidents and multiple cars in ditches were reported in those counties as well. Nearly all schools along and south of M-59, including Livingston County schools, closed on Valentine's Day due to the very poor road conditions. A 70 year old man from Roseville died (indirectly) of a heart attack while shoveling snow. The snow ended by sunrise on the 14th, but poor visibilities persisted for several more hours as the wind continued to blow the snow around. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals from each county:|Morenci (Lenawee) 5.8 inches.|Dundee (Monroe) 8.4 inches.|Monroe (Monroe)  7.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 7.0 inches.|Wyandotte (Wayne) 8.5 inches.|Troy (Oakland)  7.0 inches.|Sterling Heights (Macomb)  8.2 inches.|Ruby (St Clair)  6.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 7 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another heavy lake effect snow event impacted the thumb for the second time in only 3 days. The snow started around daybreak when northeast winds combined with a reinforcing shot of arctic air to push bands of heavy snow inland. Spotters were reporting that up to 6 inches had fallen by early afternoon. By the time the snow ended later in the day, as much as 8 inches of snow had fallen over portions of the thumb. A 50 car pile-up occurred on Interstate 69 just south of Lapeer when a heavy lake effect snow shower dumped a quick inch of snow and briefly reduced the visibility to near zero. The accident occurred at 1420 EST and closed a 5 mile stretch of both lanes for several hours. No serious injuries or fatalities were reported but multiple minor injuries were sustained.|Richmondville (Sanilac County)  8.0 inches.|Port Sanilac (Sanilac County)  8.0 inches.|Kinde (Huron County)  7.5 inches.|Harbor Beach (Huron County)  6.0 inches.|Port Huron (St Clair County) 5.1 inches.

A bitter cold airmass blasted into the region on Saturday, February the 3rd and persisted through Tuesday, February the 6th. Temperatures through this period were 20 to 25 degrees below normal. Daytime temps struggled to reach 10 degrees while subzero temperatures occurred all 3 nights. Flint set 2 temperature records and was held to a daytime temperature less than 5 degrees for the first time in over 10 years. Winds of 15 to 25 MPH gusted as high as 35 MPH at times. After factoring in the winds, apparent temperatures ranged from 15 below to 25 below through nearly the entire event. Almost every school district in Southeast Michigan canceled school on Monday and most did the same on Tuesday, citing conditions too dangerous for the kids either walking to school or waiting outside for the bus. Area hospitals reported numerous cases of patients suffering from cold related illnesses. Most of the cases involved frostbite. At least one fatality was blamed on the cold weather. Frozen pipes and water main breaks occurred throughout all of Southeast Michigan, leaving many residents and business owners out in the cold. Area homeless shelters were filled to capacity. There were also many cases of fire sprinkler lines freezing and breaking, leading to flooding. AAA Michigan reported over 20,000 vehicle service calls due to the cold air, the most in nearly 10 years. Total damages were roughly estimated at $425K, including electrical and mechanical damages to vehicles and property damages caused by flooding. Here are the official maximum and minimum temperatures observed at Detroit, Flint, and Saginaw, from the 4th through the 6th:|Detroit: 8/-2 on the 4th,  12/-4 on the 5th,  12/-3 on the 6th.|Flint: 4/-5 on the 4th,  9/-7 on the 5th,  11/-5 on the 6th.|Saginaw: 5/-7 on the 4th,  10/-7 on the 5th,  10/-6 on the 6th.

A low pressure system tracking from the Plains into the central Great Lakes dropped widespread heavy snow across west and central Upper Michigan from the 1st into the 2nd. Occasionally heavy lake effect snow developed behind the system on the night of the 2nd and continued into the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports of ten inches of snow in 18 hours were estimated over southern Ontonagon County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm tracked in from the gulf states with abundant moisture. Cold air was in place across far southern Lower Michigan, allowing the precipation to fall in the form of snow, which was heavy in many locations. Accumulations across the area ranged from six inches to more than a foot. The highest amounts ranging from 12 to 14 inches were found across much of St. Joseph and western parts of Branch county. Many schools and business were closed the following day due to the snow as well as strong winds which caused large drifts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to nine inches of snow fell along with blowing and drifting snow, creating difficult travel conditions for the entire county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving slowly across the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate snow to portions of western Upper Michigan on the 25th and 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mohawk reported inch per hour snowfall rates and measured 5.5 inches of total snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and potent storm in the Upper Great Lakes drove a cold front through Lower Michigan during the evening and overnight hours on October 18th and 19th. The atmosphere ahead of the cold front was very warm, moist, and unstable. These conditions combined with the strong storm to produce a late-season and late-night tornado outbreak. Five tornadoes were confirmed in Southeast Michigan in Shiawassee, Genesee, Tuscola, and Huron Counties. Only a couple of minor injuries were reported. Total property damages were estimated around $1.5M.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down at 0016EST, just southwest of the town of Millington, near the intersection of Barnes and Fulmer roads. It tracked northeastward and was on the ground for 2 miles before lifting near Main street and Caine Road in Millington. This tornado was rated a strong EF1 with winds estimated around 105 mph. A modular home was completely destroyed, another home received substantial damage after being battered by debris from the destroyed modular home and a framed house lost a section of its roof. Miraculously, a 14-month-old baby, sleeping in a crib in the modular home, received only minor cuts and bruises after being tossed 25 feet and buried under about 4 feet of beams, rafters, and other debris from the demolished home. Total property damages were estimated at $500K. The average path width was 30 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred in Alger and northern Schoolcraft counties from the evening of the 30th continuing into the morning of December 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported 10 inches of snow in a 24-hour period ending on the morning of December 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low pressure system rapidly intensified to the northwest of Northern Michigan.  Lake effect snow and very strong winds developed after a cold front passed on the morning of the 27th.  Charlevoix and Pellston both measured wind gusts around 60 mph by midday.  Some trees and power lines were downed as a result.  One building in Boyne City was significantly damaged by a falling tree.  Snowfall in the snowbelts was generally two inches or less.  However, a narrow band of about four inches fell from Norwood to Grayling.  The snow and gusty winds combined to produce near blizzard conditions at times.|Further north, snowfall amounts were even higher in Eastern Upper Michigan, with five to locally eight inches in western Chippewa County.  However, winds were much less this far north, and the impact of the storm was less severe.

A fast-moving low pressure system moved across Upper Michigan on the 28th, spreading 1 to 3 inches of snow across Northern Michigan.  As the low departed, cold west winds brought locally heavy lake effect snow to parts of Northern Lower Michigan on the morning of the 29th.  Elmira, Gaylord, Clarion, and Boyne City picked up 6 to 7 inches of snowfall.  Gusty winds produced a considerable amount of blowing and drifting snow.

A low pressure system tracked from Arkansas to the Upper Ohio Valley and spread heavy snow north into Michigan. This Valentine's snowstorm marked the season's first snowfall over 2 inches for much of the affected area. Northeasterly winds frequently gusted to 30 MPH and created extensive blowing and drifting snow. In addition, temperatures were in the single digits with wind chill values around 15 below zero. The snow began Tuesday afternoon of the 13th and became heavy at times through the evening and into the early morning hours of the 14th. The winds made it extremely difficult to measure the snow, but trained spotters estimated 6 to 9 inches of snow fell on areas along and east of a line from Port Huron to Adrian. Snow drifts from 3 to 5 feet were reported across this same area. A number of county roads were impassable, prompting officials to close some roads. Several motorists had to be rescued when their vehicles became stuck in snow drifts in Lenawee County. Although lesser amounts of snow (3 to 5 inches) fell across Livingston, Genesee, and Lapeer Counties, numerous accidents and multiple cars in ditches were reported in those counties as well. Nearly all schools along and south of M-59, including Livingston County schools, closed on Valentine's Day due to the very poor road conditions. A 70 year old man from Roseville died (indirectly) of a heart attack while shoveling snow. The snow ended by sunrise on the 14th, but poor visibilities persisted for several more hours as the wind continued to blow the snow around. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals from each county:|Morenci (Lenawee) 5.8 inches.|Dundee (Monroe) 8.4 inches.|Monroe (Monroe)  7.0 inches.|Ann Arbor (Washtenaw) 7.0 inches.|Wyandotte (Wayne) 8.5 inches.|Troy (Oakland)  7.0 inches.|Sterling Heights (Macomb)  8.2 inches.|Ruby (St Clair)  6.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 3 to 5 inches of snow with drifts up to a foot. Considerable blowing and drifting snow caused over 50 accidents with an additional 20 cars sliding off the road and into ditches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving over Lake Superior on the morning of the 27th produced strong, gusty northerly winds and lake effect snow in its wake across the west and central Lake Superior shoreline areas of Upper Michigan. Downed trees and power lines were reported throughout the region as well as other property damage. Brief blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northerly wind gusts ranged from 40 to 70 mph at the Copper Harbor ASOS for three hours as visibility dipped to one half mile or lower in snow and blowing snow. Blizzard conditions were observed for two hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving over Lake Superior on the morning of the 27th produced strong, gusty northerly winds and lake effect snow in its wake across the west and central Lake Superior shoreline areas of Upper Michigan. Downed trees and power lines were reported throughout the region as well as other property damage. Brief blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Briefly heavy lake effect snow accumulating from 1 to 4 inches along with northerly winds gusting between 40 to 70 mph produced blizzard conditions for two hours in Marquette. Several minor traffic accidents were attributed to the blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving over Lake Superior on the morning of the 27th produced strong, gusty northerly winds and lake effect snow in its wake across the west and central Lake Superior shoreline areas of Upper Michigan. Downed trees and power lines were reported throughout the region as well as other property damage. Brief blizzard conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in the city of Marquette, Chocolay township in Harvey and Ely Township, southwest of Marquette. Marquette's Presque Isle Park was also closed due to numerous trees and fallen debris over the roadways. About 2,800 customers had their power disrupted in the Marquette area, including Ely Township and the towns of Skandia and Harvey according to the Marquette Board of Light and Power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of an outflow boundary stretched from Illinois into portions of northern Indiana. This combined with ample moisture and instability, allowed for storms to develop in Illinois and move east, producing some reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down in Edwardsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold airmass blasted into the region on Saturday, February the 3rd and persisted through Tuesday, February the 6th. Temperatures through this period were 20 to 25 degrees below normal. Daytime temps struggled to reach 10 degrees while subzero temperatures occurred all 3 nights. Flint set 2 temperature records and was held to a daytime temperature less than 5 degrees for the first time in over 10 years. Winds of 15 to 25 MPH gusted as high as 35 MPH at times. After factoring in the winds, apparent temperatures ranged from 15 below to 25 below through nearly the entire event. Almost every school district in Southeast Michigan canceled school on Monday and most did the same on Tuesday, citing conditions too dangerous for the kids either walking to school or waiting outside for the bus. Area hospitals reported numerous cases of patients suffering from cold related illnesses. Most of the cases involved frostbite. At least one fatality was blamed on the cold weather. Frozen pipes and water main breaks occurred throughout all of Southeast Michigan, leaving many residents and business owners out in the cold. Area homeless shelters were filled to capacity. There were also many cases of fire sprinkler lines freezing and breaking, leading to flooding. AAA Michigan reported over 20,000 vehicle service calls due to the cold air, the most in nearly 10 years. Total damages were roughly estimated at $425K, including electrical and mechanical damages to vehicles and property damages caused by flooding. Here are the official maximum and minimum temperatures observed at Detroit, Flint, and Saginaw, from the 4th through the 6th:|Detroit: 8/-2 on the 4th,  12/-4 on the 5th,  12/-3 on the 6th.|Flint: 4/-5 on the 4th,  9/-7 on the 5th,  11/-5 on the 6th.|Saginaw: 5/-7 on the 4th,  10/-7 on the 5th,  10/-6 on the 6th.

A surge of arctic air moved across the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan. A significant single band of lake effect snow developed and meandered across parts of far southwestern Lower Michigan. In general accumulations of 6 to 10 inches were seen into St Joseph county. However, where the band perisisted for over 24 hours, extreme snowfall amounts occured with accumulations of 15 inches in Benton Harbor area to 20 inches in Stevensville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement officials in Cassopolis reported 8.3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a slow moving cold front and lake breeze interacted with a moderately unstable, weakly capped environment to produce a small cluster of thunderstorms. The thunderstorms became severe moving through St. Joseph into Branch County before moving northeast out of the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three trees were blown down in Union City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a slow moving cold front and lake breeze interacted with a moderately unstable, weakly capped environment to produce a small cluster of thunderstorms. The thunderstorms became severe moving through St. Joseph into Branch County before moving northeast out of the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust recorded by the Sturgis AWOS.
