An historic tornado outbreak rocked Northern Lower Michigan on the afternoon and evening of October 18th.  The day started out cool and rainy, but a dry slot aloft allowed sunshine to break out in the afternoon.  Temperatures rose into the lower to middle 70s in parts of the area.  The warm and humid air was unstable enough to fuel multiple rounds of thunderstorms in the late afternoon and evening hours.  There was a tremendous amount of shear in the atmosphere, and many storms quickly became supercells with rotating updrafts.  This was an environment conducive to tornadoes, as several lines of discrete supercells crossed Northern Lower Michigan.||Northern Lower Michigan had a record six tornadoes on the day.  The previous high was five, set on June 17 1992.  Unfortunately, the Kalkaska tornado produced a fatality.  That was the first tornado fatality in Northern Lower Michigan since March 30 1976, when a single death occurred in Ogemaw County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McCollum Lake tornado developed from the same storm that produced the Oscoda County tornado.  It produced considerable tree damage along McCollum Lake Road, near the Oscoda/Alcona County line.  Only a small part of the tornado track was in Oscoda County, but most of the damage was in this initial section.  Swirl markings were seen in nearby fields.  A few outbuildings were also damaged.  The tornado continued on into Alcona County.  Winds were estimated at 105 mph, making it an EF1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An historic tornado outbreak rocked Northern Lower Michigan on the afternoon and evening of October 18th.  The day started out cool and rainy, but a dry slot aloft allowed sunshine to break out in the afternoon.  Temperatures rose into the lower to middle 70s in parts of the area.  The warm and humid air was unstable enough to fuel multiple rounds of thunderstorms in the late afternoon and evening hours.  There was a tremendous amount of shear in the atmosphere, and many storms quickly became supercells with rotating updrafts.  This was an environment conducive to tornadoes, as several lines of discrete supercells crossed Northern Lower Michigan.||Northern Lower Michigan had a record six tornadoes on the day.  The previous high was five, set on June 17 1992.  Unfortunately, the Kalkaska tornado produced a fatality.  That was the first tornado fatality in Northern Lower Michigan since March 30 1976, when a single death occurred in Ogemaw County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The third tornado from this parent thunderstorm, and sixth and final tornado of the day, this one was only on the ground momentarily, with a quarter-mile long track.  However, this quick touchdown produced substantial damage near Borke Road.  One home had its second story ripped off.  A nearby mobile home was destroyed, and two barns were significantly damaged.  Some livestock (cows and chickens) were killed.  Trees in the area were also heavily damaged.  Winds were estimated at up to 110 mph, making it an EF2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow combined with east winds gusting over 40 mph resulted in   localized blizzard conditions on the evening of the 1st and morning of the 2nd. Highway US-2 was closed from Manistique to Escanaba due to limited visibility in blowing snow. The Cooks observer measured nine inches of snow in a 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly strengthening low pressure system moved across Lower Michigan on the 4th, bringing significant and widespread snow to the region.  Winds kicked up substantially as the low reached Lake Huron, resulting in substantial blowing and drifting snow.  A few spots experienced near-blizzard conditions late on the 4th.  Those winds also brought much colder air to the region, producing lake effect snow in the snowbelts for the next several days.  The event finally wound down on the 8th.  Total snowfall amounts in excess of 6 inches were common northwest of a line from St Helen, to Mio, to Ossineke.  Local accumulations reached 18 inches near Paradise, and along the US-131 corridor from Elmira to Cadillac.  The early April snow interrupted many Easter activities, though area ski resorts were delighted to have a busy week so late in the season.

Another round of April snow blasted Northern Michigan, as low pressure moved from Illinois to central Lake Huron.  Snowfall accumulations ranged from 3 to 8 inches across most of Northern Lower Michigan, as well as east of I-75 in Eastern Upper Michigan.  The highest amounts, 6 to 8 inches, fell from Kingsley to Lake City and Cadillac, as well as from Wolverine to Lewiston and Glennie.  Blustery winds, starting out easterly and turning north and west with time, produced considerable blowing snow.  The heavy, wet snow - when combined with the gusty winds - brought down some tree limbs and power lines in Alpena County.  In Traverse City, a commercial airliner attempting to land during the snow at Cherry Capital Airport, slid off the end of the runway.  No one was injured.  At the time of this writing, it was unknown to what degree the weather conditions may have contributed to the accident.

An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy snow continued from the 5th into the 7th. The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting to 30 mph or greater reduced visibility to one-half mile or less at times in snow and blowing snow.  Storm total accumulations ending on the 7th...included over 60 inches at Painesdale, 38 inches at Atlantic Mine, 33 inches at Laurium and 31 inches at Houghton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy snow continued from the 5th into the 7th. The combination of heavy snow and north winds gusting to 30 mph or greater reduced visibility to one-half mile or less at times in heavy snow and blowing snow.  Storm total snowfall included 57 inches at Phoenix Farms and 37 inches at Mohawk.

An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy lake effect snow occurred from the 4th into 7th.  North winds gusting to 25 mph or greater also reduced visibility to one-half mile or less at times in blowing snow. Storm total snowfall ending on the 7th included 26 inches at Two Heart and 16 inches at McMillan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prescribed burn by the U.S. Forest Service on the 27th blazed out of control by the 29th fueled by low relative humidity and strong west winds gusting over 40 mph. The wildfire consumed more than 1300 acres in western Baraga County until it was mostly contained by the end of the 30th. |Another fire in northwest Marquette County destroyed three structures and burned approximately 60 acres before it was brought under control on the 29th.  A downed power line on Green Garden Road in eastern Marquette County also left 60 homes without power for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Baraga Bump Wildfire, which started as a controlled burn on the 27th, burned out of control by the 29th fueled by low relative humidities and strong west winds gusting over 40 mph. The fire  consumed more than 1300 acres in the Baraga Plains area between the 27th and 30th. More than 120 firefighters from the U.S. Forest Service and the Michigan DNR battled the blaze and helped authorities evacuate thirty homes in the Covington area.  No injures or structure damage were reported from the fire.

A cold front continued to creep across the region on the 9th.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along the front in the afternoon, producing severe weather in the Saginaw Bay region.  This included the first tornado of the year in Northern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down just west of Wolfe Road, slightly more than half a mile north of US-23.  The tornado tracked southeast, crossing Wolfe Road and lifting at US-23 north of Wyatt Road.  The roof was peeled off of a mobile home, and deposited in the backyard.  A couple of trees were downed, and a distinct path was carved in a nearby corn field.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated in excess of 50 mph caused damage at a home in Breitung Township just north of Iron Mountain on the 4th.  A large pine tree toppled and damaged a backyard deck, an air conditioning unit, a rabbit pen and caused a leak in the natural gas line.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at Garden Corners measured nine inches of snow in 24 hours. Winds gusting over 30 mph at times causing extensive blowing and drifting of snow.

An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Au Train reported frequent power outages and a large tree down.  The Munising automated observing site reported wind gusts frequently over 40 mph with a few gusts over 50 mph. Schools were closed throughout the county on the 4th and 5th due to frequent whiteout conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snowfall totals from the 4th into the evening of the 5th included 16 inches at both Shingleton and Munising.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Frequent whiteout conditions were reported throughout the county in heavy snow and blowing snow. The Houghton County Airport ASOS reported frequent wind gusts of 40 mph or more with some gusts approaching 50 mph at times. The strong winds and heavy snow downed trees across roads and powerlines south of Houghton. Area schools were closed on the 4th and 5th along with some area businesses. Law enforcement agencies reported many towed vehicles and numerous accidents due to the storm.  Total snowfall from the 4th into the 5th included 38 inches at Painesdale and 22 inches at Laurium with three-inch per hour snowfall rates reported at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow continued at times from late on the 4th through the morning of the 7th. Northerly winds were frequently gusting to 30 mph or greater reducing visibility to one-half mile or less at times  in snow and blowing snow. Storm total snowfall accumulations included 48 inches at NWS Marquette...27 inches at Green Garden...25 inches at Champion and 20 inches in downtown Marquette.  The calendar day snowfall total of 24 inches at NWS Marquette on the 4th was the second highest total ever for any calendar day at the station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly strengthening low pressure system moved across Lower Michigan on the 4th, bringing significant and widespread snow to the region.  Winds kicked up substantially as the low reached Lake Huron, resulting in substantial blowing and drifting snow.  A few spots experienced near-blizzard conditions late on the 4th.  Those winds also brought much colder air to the region, producing lake effect snow in the snowbelts for the next several days.  The event finally wound down on the 8th.  Total snowfall amounts in excess of 6 inches were common northwest of a line from St Helen, to Mio, to Ossineke.  Local accumulations reached 18 inches near Paradise, and along the US-131 corridor from Elmira to Cadillac.  The early April snow interrupted many Easter activities, though area ski resorts were delighted to have a busy week so late in the season.

An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at Ironwood measured 24 inches of snow from the 3rd into the morning of the 5th. There was a break in snowfall through much of the 5th into the afternoon of the 6th. More snow then fell late on the 6th into midday on the 7th with an additional 5 inches at Ironwood and 8 to 10 inches at Wakefield. |North winds gusted over 30 mph at times on the 4th and caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and hazardous travel conditions. Some schools closed on the 4th...including Gogebic Community College.  A few minor accidents were reported due to the snow and ice-packed roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at Watton measured 10.4 inches of snow in the 24 hour period ending on the 4th. There were several minor accidents on the 4th due to the heavy snow. There was generally a break in heavy snow from the 5th into the morning of the 6th before another 12 inches of snow fell at Herman during the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.  Storm total snowfall ending on the morning of the 7th included 35 inches at Herman...21 inches at Watton and 16 inches at Baraga.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snow fell in 24 hours along Highway M-38 from the night of the 3rd into the morning of the 4th. There was generally a break in heavy snow on the 5th and 6th.  Another disturbance moving across Lake Superior brought another ten inches of lake enhanced snow to areas along Highway M-38 during the night of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter along Highway M-77 near the Alger County border observed 33 inches of storm total snowfall ending on the 7th. Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph or greater at times also caused occasional whiteout conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All flights into and out of K.I. Sawyer International were cancelled on the 4th as whiteout conditions were reported on the runways. Wind gusts greater than 35 mph were reported at the K.I. Sawyer AWOS through much of the day with visibility of one-quarter mile or less. Whiteout conditions were also reported in downtown Marquette as many area schools were closed, including Northern Michigan University. In addition, about 3000 Marquette Board of Light and Power customers lost power in various locations throughout Marquette County on the 4th as downed trees fell across power lines. Several minor accidents were also reported on area roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Frequent wind gusts in excess of 40 mph caused whiteout conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snowfall totals from the 4th through the 5th included 40 inches at Phoenix and 21 inches at Mohawk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow continued at times from late on the 5th through the morning of the 7th. Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph or greater caused reduced visibilities of one-half mile or less in snow and blowing snow. Storm total snowfall accumulations included 38 inches south of Grand Marais, 33 inches at Munising and south of Wetmore and 24 inches at Shingleton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of April snow blasted Northern Michigan, as low pressure moved from Illinois to central Lake Huron.  Snowfall accumulations ranged from 3 to 8 inches across most of Northern Lower Michigan, as well as east of I-75 in Eastern Upper Michigan.  The highest amounts, 6 to 8 inches, fell from Kingsley to Lake City and Cadillac, as well as from Wolverine to Lewiston and Glennie.  Blustery winds, starting out easterly and turning north and west with time, produced considerable blowing snow.  The heavy, wet snow - when combined with the gusty winds - brought down some tree limbs and power lines in Alpena County.  In Traverse City, a commercial airliner attempting to land during the snow at Cherry Capital Airport, slid off the end of the runway.  No one was injured.  At the time of this writing, it was unknown to what degree the weather conditions may have contributed to the accident.

A prescribed burn by the U.S. Forest Service on the 27th blazed out of control by the 29th fueled by low relative humidity and strong west winds gusting over 40 mph. The wildfire consumed more than 1300 acres in western Baraga County until it was mostly contained by the end of the 30th. |Another fire in northwest Marquette County destroyed three structures and burned approximately 60 acres before it was brought under control on the 29th.  A downed power line on Green Garden Road in eastern Marquette County also left 60 homes without power for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire in Powell Township near Big Bay destroyed three structures including an abandoned VFW hall on the 29th. The fire burned approximately sixty acres before it was brought under control. |A fire-related power outage on Green Garden Road in eastern Marquette County left sixty homes without power for several hours on the 29th.

A strong low pressure system approached the region from the southwest.  Associated precipitation spread northward into the region on the 1st.  Eastern Upper Michigan stayed all snow, mixed with sleet and freezing rain at times in far Northern Lower Michigan, and turned over to all freezing rain further south.  Precipitation was turning showery during this transition time, so significant accumulations of ice were localized.  Still, Cadillac picked up around a quarter-inch of ice accumulation, and East Tawas and Oscoda had almost an inch of glaze - on top of a few inches of snow.  Some power lines were downed near both Cadillac and Tawas.  A number of large tree limbs were downed in Iosco County, one of which destroyed a shed.  To the north, the snowfall was heavy, with 16 inches in Rogers City, 14 inches in Paradise, and 11 inches in Comins.  Strong easterly winds were enhanced by showery precipitation, with some gusts in excess of 50 mph.  Trees were downed in the Gaylord area, damaging a home.  Downed power lines were also common, thanks to the winds and the heavy, wet snow which clung to lines.  Substantial blowing and drifting snow occurred where precipitation stayed all snow.  A number of school districts closed early on the 1st, and stayed closed through the 2nd.

A strong low pressure system brought a combination of snow and ice to central lower Michigan.  The maximum snowfall from this event was 8 to 9 inches and up to a half of an inch of ice accumulation was also reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of snow and three tenths of an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought a combination of snow and ice to central lower Michigan.  The maximum snowfall from this event was 8 to 9 inches and up to a half of an inch of ice accumulation was also reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inches of snow and three tenths of an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed behind a synoptic low pressure system which moved through our area on March first.  Twelve to as much as fifteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan, Ottawa, and western Kent counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to fourteen inches of snow was reported across portions of western Kent county.

A strong storm system originating over the southern Plains brought heavy snow and extensive blowing snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st continuing into the 3rd. Some rumbles of thunder even accompanied the system on the evening of the 1st...coincident with reports of freezing rain and sleet over Iron, Dickinson and Menominee counties. East wind gusts in excess of 50 mph produced blizzard or near-blizzard conditions at times mainly over the Keweenaw Peninsula and near the bay of Green Bay. Storm total snowfall exceeded 10 inches over all but south central portions of Upper Michigan. The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township reported the most snow with 31 inches. |Many school districts throughout Upper Michigan were closed on the 2nd as road plow crews worked steadily at clearing snow from roadways. Northern Michigan University, Michigan Tech University and Bay College in Delta County were also closed on the 2nd.  Numerous streets and businesses in Houghton, including the Houghton County courthouse, were closed on the 2nd due to blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts included 31 inches at the NWS Office in  Negaunee Township, 22 inches at Champion and Marquette, 18 inches at Big Bay and 17 inches at Ishpeming and Green Garden. East to northeast winds gusting to around 30 mph caused frequent whiteout conditions and considerable drifting of snow on the 1st into the morning of the 2nd.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 2nd...including Northern Michigan University.

An intense storm system tracking from the Plains into the Great Lakes  dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the 7th. Blizzard to near-blizzard conditions also occurred from the 4th continuing into the 5th closing many schools and businesses throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at Rockland measured 34 inches of snow from the 3rd into the morning of the 5th with an additional 10 inches of snow from late on the 6th into the morning of the 7th. Occasional whiteout conditions were also reported along with numerous minor accidents on the 3rd and 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major severe weather event of the season resulted in widespread reports of wind damage and large hail. This event can be best described as having two parts. The first round of severe storms occurred well in advance of the actual cold front. One batch formed southwest of the Metro-Detroit area, and another formed in the Saginaw valley and thumb regions. A strong supercell moved across Huron County, producing 70 MPH wind gusts and baseball sized hail. A second and final round of storms developed along the cold front with a squall line actually moving from the southwest to the northeast. The squall line raced across the region and produced wind gusts in the 60-70 mph range. Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper article reported that a house suffered heavy damage after a lightning strike ignited a fire. Total damages were roughly estimated at $75K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major severe weather event of the season resulted in widespread reports of wind damage and large hail. This event can be best described as having two parts. The first round of severe storms occurred well in advance of the actual cold front. One batch formed southwest of the Metro-Detroit area, and another formed in the Saginaw valley and thumb regions. A strong supercell moved across Huron County, producing 70 MPH wind gusts and baseball sized hail. A second and final round of storms developed along the cold front with a squall line actually moving from the southwest to the northeast. The squall line raced across the region and produced wind gusts in the 60-70 mph range. Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper reported that a coal stacker at the Karn-Weadock power plant was destroyed after being toppled by thunderstorm winds. A plant spokesman estimated wind gusts at 80 MPH. Total damages were estimated at roughly $1.5M.

The first major severe weather event of the season resulted in widespread reports of wind damage and large hail. This event can be best described as having two parts. The first round of severe storms occurred well in advance of the actual cold front. One batch formed southwest of the Metro-Detroit area, and another formed in the Saginaw valley and thumb regions. A strong supercell moved across Huron County, producing 70 MPH wind gusts and baseball sized hail. A second and final round of storms developed along the cold front with a squall line actually moving from the southwest to the northeast. The squall line raced across the region and produced wind gusts in the 60-70 mph range. Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported trees down across a major highway. One of the trees fell on a vehicle. An occupant of the vehicle suffered minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from about Chicago to Cleveland along a warm front during the day. This provided enough support for a few thunderstorms to become severe from Detroit southwest to the Ohio border during the afternoon. The severe weather from these storms came in the form of large hail. The strongest storm clipped Lenawee County, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from about Chicago to Cleveland along a warm front during the day. This provided enough support for a few thunderstorms to become severe from Detroit southwest to the Ohio border during the afternoon. The severe weather from these storms came in the form of large hail. The strongest storm clipped Lenawee County, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls.
An isolated pulse severe event near Highland resulted in large tree branches down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service employee reported large tree branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated pulse severe event near Highland resulted in large tree branches down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down.

The first major severe weather event of the season resulted in widespread reports of wind damage and large hail. This event can be best described as having two parts. The first round of severe storms occurred well in advance of the actual cold front. One batch formed southwest of the Metro-Detroit area, and another formed in the Saginaw valley and thumb regions. A strong supercell moved across Huron County, producing 70 MPH wind gusts and baseball sized hail. A second and final round of storms developed along the cold front with a squall line actually moving from the southwest to the northeast. The squall line raced across the region and produced wind gusts in the 60-70 mph range. Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported trees down, with one on a garage. Damages to the garage were estimated at roughly $12K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating allowed thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of the 30th.  A few storms became severe in Northeast Lower Michigan.
Numerous thunderstorms developed during the warmest part of the day, with lake breezes serving as the initial trigger.  Some storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed near West Otsego Lake Drive and Johns Street.  Another tree was felled on Old State Road near I-75.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced several reports of large hail and high winds which brought down several trees and branches in Kalamazoo, Calhoun, Jackson, Eaton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced one inch diameter hail and estimated wind gusts to 60 m.p.h. which brought down several six inch diameter trees two miles west of Burlington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced several reports of large hail and high winds which brought down several trees and branches in Kalamazoo, Calhoun, Jackson, Eaton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of six trees and large limbs were blown down on a golf|course one mile northeast of Pleasant Lake in Jackson county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced several reports of large hail and high winds which brought down several trees and branches in Kalamazoo, Calhoun, Jackson, Eaton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms blew down several large trees as well as shingles off of a greenhouse one mile south of Lansing in Ingham county.  A one and a half foot diameter tree was also blown down onto a home causing major roof damage in Williamston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds funneled into southeastern Michigan when the area found itself located between two weather systems, a strong high pressure system to the west and a powerful Nor'easter to the east. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 MPH, with frequent gusts between 45 and 50 MPH, whipped through the area on Tuesday afternoon, April 16th. Tragically, the winds were to blame for a fatality at the Roosevelt Primary School in Ferndale. The winds snapped a 45 foot tall flagpole at the elementary school. The metal pole fell and struck a 5 year old kindergartner. The young girl died from her injuries. A trained weather spotter estimated wind gusts to 50 MPH in Troy (southern Oakland County). Numerous branches, power lines, and several trees were blown down by the winds. Up to 50,000 customers lost power. Total damages were roughly estimated at around $160K and primarily included damages to homes and electrical poles. Here are some of the highest wind gusts measured across the region: Grand Blanc (Genesee) 54 MPH, Harbor Beach (Huron) 50 MPH, Mt Clemens (Macomb) 48 MPH, Port Huron (St Clair) 47 MPH, Detroit City Airport (Wayne) 47 MPH, Pontiac (Oakland) 45 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported that at least 3 trees fell onto homes in Fair Haven in St Clair County. Downed power lines forced authorities to temporarily close off Interstate 94.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season blast of Arctic air led to a few lake effect snow squalls that caused a multi-car accident in the Fenton area and several rollover accidents in the Ann Arbor area on the night before Easter. All of the accidents occurred around 1800 EST when intense snow squalls briefly resulted in near whiteout conditions. Temperatures were in the 20s and roads were reportedly very icy. At least 25 vehicles crashed on US 23 in the Fenton area. The police locked down both lanes of the expressway for 3 hours, from Owen Road to Thompson Road. In northeast Ann Arbor, at least six vehicles flipped over during an intense snow squall. No serious injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm wind gust blew down wires across portions of Delta township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced several reports of large hail and high winds which brought down several trees and branches in Kalamazoo, Calhoun, Jackson, Eaton and Ingham counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced very high wind gusts of up to 75 to 85 m.p.h. and also several reports of large hail across southern Kalamazoo county.  ||The worst of the damage occurred around 5:52 p.m. in the area south of Portage and north of Vicksburg. A path of damage one mile wide and one and a half miles long started near the Portage Road and U Avenue intersection.  The damage continued northeast to just south of the 24th street and S Avenue intersection.  ||Highest wind speeds of 75 to 85 m.p.h. were determined by NOAA's National Weather Service Grand Rapids storm survey team.  Within this|area a roof on a pole barn was partially blown off.  A garage|door was blown in and some roofing and siding material was stripped off of several homes.  Many large healthy trees were uprooted or snapped off.  Some trees were lying on houses and all damage was lying to the northeast indicating straight line winds.

Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down and estimated the wind gusts at 65 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major severe weather event of the season resulted in widespread reports of wind damage and large hail. This event can be best described as having two parts. The first round of severe storms occurred well in advance of the actual cold front. One batch formed southwest of the Metro-Detroit area, and another formed in the Saginaw valley and thumb regions. A strong supercell moved across Huron County, producing 70 MPH wind gusts and baseball sized hail. A second and final round of storms developed along the cold front with a squall line actually moving from the southwest to the northeast. The squall line raced across the region and produced wind gusts in the 60-70 mph range. Numerous reports of wind damage were received in a swath stretching from a Jackson/Adrian line, northeast to a Flint/Imlay City line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds funneled into southeastern Michigan when the area found itself located between two weather systems, a strong high pressure system to the west and a powerful Nor'easter to the east. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 MPH, with frequent gusts between 45 and 50 MPH, whipped through the area on Tuesday afternoon, April 16th. Tragically, the winds were to blame for a fatality at the Roosevelt Primary School in Ferndale. The winds snapped a 45 foot tall flagpole at the elementary school. The metal pole fell and struck a 5 year old kindergartner. The young girl died from her injuries. A trained weather spotter estimated wind gusts to 50 MPH in Troy (southern Oakland County). Numerous branches, power lines, and several trees were blown down by the winds. Up to 50,000 customers lost power. Total damages were roughly estimated at around $160K and primarily included damages to homes and electrical poles. Here are some of the highest wind gusts measured across the region: Grand Blanc (Genesee) 54 MPH, Harbor Beach (Huron) 50 MPH, Mt Clemens (Macomb) 48 MPH, Port Huron (St Clair) 47 MPH, Detroit City Airport (Wayne) 47 MPH, Pontiac (Oakland) 45 MPH.

A potent line of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan, and moved across Northern Lower Michigan in the early overnight hours.  These storms produced a considerable amount of wind damage, especially in Northwest Lower Michigan.  There were a number of power outages, most widespread in the Cadillac area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many large trees were downed in northern Missaukee County.  Several structures and trailers were damaged by falling trees, especially in and just west of Moorestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent line of thunderstorms developed over Lake Michigan, and moved across Northern Lower Michigan in the early overnight hours.  These storms produced a considerable amount of wind damage, especially in Northwest Lower Michigan.  There were a number of power outages, most widespread in the Cadillac area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed.  One tree fell onto a century-old cottage, causing substantial damage to the roof and porch, and shattering windows.  Large limbs were downed at the Grand Hotel golf course, and fencing was damaging along Huron Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of thunderstorms developed along a cold front, just before it exited Northern Michigan.  One severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Alpena County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and a few large tree limbs were downed on 2nd Avenue and on Sable Street, near the northern city limits of Alpena.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms affected much of southwestern lower Michigan, resulting in several reports of large hail and numerous reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A state trooper reported seven eighths inch diameter hail along US-131 three miles north of Rockford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms affected much of southwestern lower Michigan, resulting in several reports of large hail and numerous reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Police reported hail and torrential rain at the south side of Covert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms affected much of southwestern lower Michigan, resulting in several reports of large hail and numerous reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five trees were blown down in Grand Junction.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous waves of thunderstorms affected southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening of June 27, 2007. Severe storms developed along and ahead of a cold front, which dropped south through a very warm and humid airmass. There were numerous reports of wind damage and hail. Saginaw County received two separate rounds of severe weather, producing hail to one-inch in diameter and a number of reports of trees and power poles blown down by winds. Flooding was also a concern, as some areas were repeatedly affected by complexes of storms. Northern Shiawassee County received the worst flooding, with National Weather Service radar estimating up to six inches of rainfall in just a few hours. A golfer in northwest Detroit was struck by lightning and killed after seeking refuge under a tree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a tree 2 1/2 feet in diameter down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture, associated with the remnants of tropical system Barry, interacted with a slow moving cold front and resulted in numerous thunderstorms with intense rainfall for much of the afternoon west of US-23. Radar indicated 4 to 6 inches of rain fell between 1300 EST and 1600 EST on Sunday June 3rd. The heaviest rain fell from Parkers Corner in Livingston County to just northwest of Manchester and as far east as Hell and Chelsea with Gregory caught in the middle. Runoff from the heavy rain caused a significant rise on the upper chain of lakes, including Patterson, Bass, Half Moon, Bruin, etc. Lake levels rose for several days and reached unofficial record levels on Thursday June 7th when flood waters reportedly peaked. Shoreline flooding along the inland lakes affected many homes and cottages. It took nearly 2 weeks for lake levels to recede to original levels. In addition to the flooding, a downburst of wind coming out of a thunderstorm struck the ground and caused localized damage in extreme southeastern Monroe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local newspaper article reported at least 8 utility poles, along M-125 between Sterns and Benore Roads, had snapped in half due to high winds in a thunderstorm. Total damages were estimated at roughly $20K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid air settled into the region behind a warm front, setting off a couple of severe thunderstorms in Huron County. These storms were responsible for multiple incidents of farm outbuilding damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported two barns blown down. Total damages were estimated at roughly $30K.

Total property damages were estimated at roughly $50K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed on a very warm and moist Saturday afternoon. One area of severe storms moved through Shiawassee and northern Genesee Counties, producing wind damage and two reports of severe hail. Another area of storms formed farther to the south, leading to several reports of wind damage. There was also one report of a large tree down on a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large trees and power lines down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree 1 foot in diameter down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed on a very warm and moist Saturday afternoon. One area of severe storms moved through Shiawassee and northern Genesee Counties, producing wind damage and two reports of severe hail. Another area of storms formed farther to the south, leading to several reports of wind damage. There was also one report of a large tree down on a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported many large tree branches down, as well as a few trees. One tree fell on a garage, causing some structural damage. Property damages were roughly estimated at $3K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous waves of thunderstorms affected southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening of June 27, 2007. Severe storms developed along and ahead of a cold front, which dropped south through a very warm and humid airmass. There were numerous reports of wind damage and hail. Saginaw County received two separate rounds of severe weather, producing hail to one-inch in diameter and a number of reports of trees and power poles blown down by winds. Flooding was also a concern, as some areas were repeatedly affected by complexes of storms. Northern Shiawassee County received the worst flooding, with National Weather Service radar estimating up to six inches of rainfall in just a few hours. A golfer in northwest Detroit was struck by lightning and killed after seeking refuge under a tree.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported two large tree branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in advance of a strong cold front. A few of the storms became severe, having the biggest impact across Wayne County. Wind gusts as high as 65 MPH blew down several trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a tree 2 feet in diameter down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in advance of a strong cold front. A few of the storms became severe, having the biggest impact across Wayne County. Wind gusts as high as 65 MPH blew down several trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 3 to 4 trees down at a marina on the Lost Peninsula.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in advance of a strong cold front. A few of the storms became severe, having the biggest impact across Wayne County. Wind gusts as high as 65 MPH blew down several trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed in advance of a strong cold front. A few of the storms became severe, having the biggest impact across Wayne County. Wind gusts as high as 65 MPH blew down several trees and power lines.

Deep moisture, associated with the remnants of tropical system Barry, interacted with a slow moving cold front and resulted in numerous thunderstorms with intense rainfall for much of the afternoon west of US-23. Radar indicated 4 to 6 inches of rain fell between 1300 EST and 1600 EST on Sunday June 3rd. The heaviest rain fell from Parkers Corner in Livingston County to just northwest of Manchester and as far east as Hell and Chelsea with Gregory caught in the middle. Runoff from the heavy rain caused a significant rise on the upper chain of lakes, including Patterson, Bass, Half Moon, Bruin, etc. Lake levels rose for several days and reached unofficial record levels on Thursday June 7th when flood waters reportedly peaked. Shoreline flooding along the inland lakes affected many homes and cottages. It took nearly 2 weeks for lake levels to recede to original levels. In addition to the flooding, a downburst of wind coming out of a thunderstorm struck the ground and caused localized damage in extreme southeastern Monroe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local newspaper reports confirmed a couple dozen homes sustained flood damage. Five and a half inches of rain in only a few hours caused about a dozen basements to flood around the Gregory area on the evening of June 3rd. Additional basement flooding occurred later in the week around Lake Patterson, which finally peaked on Thursday June 7th. Flood waters finally began to recede that night. Total property damages were estimated at roughly $400K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front, slowly dropping south through the area, featured a few showers with embedded thunderstorms for much of the morning. One storm managed to produce severe wind gusts along the Michigan/Ohio border, resulting in tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down on the Lenawee/Monroe County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of downed trees and one report of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported three trees blown down two miles north of Leroy and seven eighths inch diameter hail in Leroy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms affected much of southwestern lower Michigan, resulting in several reports of large hail and numerous reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down in the Onondaga area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms affected much of southwestern lower Michigan, resulting in several reports of large hail and numerous reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were blown down along the Ingham/Jackson county line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold airmass blasted into the region, leading to intense lake effect snow squalls from Saginaw to Flint and east into Lapeer County. The squalls were narrow but intense bands that dumped up to 4 inches of snow in some areas with only trace amounts in other areas. The snow was also accompanied by wind gusts up to 40 MPH which created brief periods of near whiteout conditions. The snow squalls caused numerous accidents and multiple spinouts beginning early Wednesday evening, April 4th. The accidents continued through the night and into Thursday morning, April 5th. There were 43 weather related accidents reported in Saginaw County, at least 14 in Bay County, 46 in Lapeer County, and numerous accidents and spinouts in Genesee County. Several roads were closed, including a stretch of Interstate 75 near Birch Run after a large number of vehicles crashed on both lanes of the icy expressway. A 19 year old male was killed after an oncoming vehicle lost control on an icy road in Lapeer County (indirect). At least 2 people were critically injured in other accidents (indirect).

Strong winds funneled into southeastern Michigan when the area found itself located between two weather systems, a strong high pressure system to the west and a powerful Nor'easter to the east. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 MPH, with frequent gusts between 45 and 50 MPH, whipped through the area on Tuesday afternoon, April 16th. Tragically, the winds were to blame for a fatality at the Roosevelt Primary School in Ferndale. The winds snapped a 45 foot tall flagpole at the elementary school. The metal pole fell and struck a 5 year old kindergartner. The young girl died from her injuries. A trained weather spotter estimated wind gusts to 50 MPH in Troy (southern Oakland County). Numerous branches, power lines, and several trees were blown down by the winds. Up to 50,000 customers lost power. Total damages were roughly estimated at around $160K and primarily included damages to homes and electrical poles. Here are some of the highest wind gusts measured across the region: Grand Blanc (Genesee) 54 MPH, Harbor Beach (Huron) 50 MPH, Mt Clemens (Macomb) 48 MPH, Port Huron (St Clair) 47 MPH, Detroit City Airport (Wayne) 47 MPH, Pontiac (Oakland) 45 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A substation was heavily damaged when flying debris flew into it. Nearly 5000 customers lost power as a result.

Very dry and windy conditions fueled a wildfire that took out over 100 acres of brush and reeds in and around Metro Beach Metropark in Harrison Township. Winds in the area were gusting to as high as 50 MPH at the time of the fire. Fire officials from eight communities battled the blaze for over two hours and successfully contained it from spreading into more populated areas.

A very cold airmass blasted into the region, leading to intense lake effect snow squalls from Saginaw to Flint and east into Lapeer County. The squalls were narrow but intense bands that dumped up to 4 inches of snow in some areas with only trace amounts in other areas. The snow was also accompanied by wind gusts up to 40 MPH which created brief periods of near whiteout conditions. The snow squalls caused numerous accidents and multiple spinouts beginning early Wednesday evening, April 4th. The accidents continued through the night and into Thursday morning, April 5th. There were 43 weather related accidents reported in Saginaw County, at least 14 in Bay County, 46 in Lapeer County, and numerous accidents and spinouts in Genesee County. Several roads were closed, including a stretch of Interstate 75 near Birch Run after a large number of vehicles crashed on both lanes of the icy expressway. A 19 year old male was killed after an oncoming vehicle lost control on an icy road in Lapeer County (indirect). At least 2 people were critically injured in other accidents (indirect).

Severe thunderstorm wind gusts brought down numerous trees across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large severe weather event unfolded on August 23rd and resulted in numerous reports of wind damage.  A confirmed tornado in Montcalm county resulted in minimal damage to several sheds and thousands of trees were either uprooted or snapped off in a rural portion of the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down in Wacousta and a two foot diameter tree was blown onto a car in DeWitt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced widespread wind damage with numerous reports of downed trees and power lines across far southern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down across Clinton county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down and blocked area roads in Sonoma and Athens as well as two miles north of Burlington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm dropped large hail at Faithorn on the evening of the 10th.
Severe thunderstorms dropped large hail over portions of Baraga and Keweenaw counties on the evening of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly pea with some penny hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms dropped large hail over portions of Baraga and Keweenaw counties on the evening of the 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-sized hail also reported five miles west of Phoenix at the same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed over the region during the late afternoon hours of July 5th. There were numerous reports of large hail and damaging winds. The most intense winds occurred along a path stretching from just south of Saginaw to just north of Pontiac. These intense thunderstorm winds, gusting as high as 70 MPH, brought down many large trees. Remarkably, only a few homes sustained minor damages. There were also reports of large hail, some the size of ping pong balls. Numerous trees were also blown down across Livingston County, especially around the Fowlerville area. By sunset, the atmosphere became less capable of supporting severe thunderstorms and the event was over. No injuries were reported. At least 50 thousand customers lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported 4 trees down and 7 utility poles snapped. Wind gusts were estimated at 70 MPH.

A very unstable airmass coupled with a stalled out front was enough to fuel the development of two extremely intense thunderstorms. One of the storms managed to go from Mount Pleasant all the way to eastern Oakland County. The storm in Midland County became so intense that it prompted the issuance of a Tornado Warning. National Weather Service field surveys identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The Sanford area was hardest hit with many homes suffering damages from falling trees. Many local businesses in Sanford and Midland implemented tornado safety plans, moving customers to designated shelter areas. St Charles in Saginaw County was another area hit hard from downburst winds approaching 80 MPH. Total damages from the entire event approached nearly a quarter of a million dollars.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree down on the northwest side of Midland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This event will be remembered for the extreme intensity of large hail it generated. A most unusual hailstorm pounded areas in a 3 mile radius around the city of Durand. Severe hail fell for nearly an hour. At times, the hail was as big as golf balls. Hundreds of homes and vehicles suffered significant damages, totaling nearly 5 million dollars in this area alone. Large hail also caused significant damages to cars in and around the Adrian area. Mostly hail reports were received, but we did get a few wind damage reports from thunderstorm downbursts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass coupled with a stalled out front was enough to fuel the development of two extremely intense thunderstorms. One of the storms managed to go from Mount Pleasant all the way to eastern Oakland County. The storm in Midland County became so intense that it prompted the issuance of a Tornado Warning. National Weather Service field surveys identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The Sanford area was hardest hit with many homes suffering damages from falling trees. Many local businesses in Sanford and Midland implemented tornado safety plans, moving customers to designated shelter areas. St Charles in Saginaw County was another area hit hard from downburst winds approaching 80 MPH. Total damages from the entire event approached nearly a quarter of a million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a large tree down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service field survey confirmed that 70 to 80 MPH straight line winds blew down numerous large trees. Several homes were damaged from the falling trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service field survey confirmed that straight line winds as high as 80 MPH blew down numerous large trees, including 10 huge oak trees on M-30 near Dague Road. These trees caused significant damages after falling on one family's home, pole barn, car and truck. Total damages were estimated at $60K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed over the region during the late afternoon hours of July 5th. There were numerous reports of large hail and damaging winds. The most intense winds occurred along a path stretching from just south of Saginaw to just north of Pontiac. These intense thunderstorm winds, gusting as high as 70 MPH, brought down many large trees. Remarkably, only a few homes sustained minor damages. There were also reports of large hail, some the size of ping pong balls. Numerous trees were also blown down across Livingston County, especially around the Fowlerville area. By sunset, the atmosphere became less capable of supporting severe thunderstorms and the event was over. No injuries were reported. At least 50 thousand customers lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement and a local newspaper reported several trees down in Marion Township.

Drought conditions (severe, D2) expanded into the tip of Northern Michigan by the end of August.  The was the result of a dry summer in the region.  The dryness dated as far back as May, when only 1.09 inches of rain fell in Pellston.  June rainfall was 1.92 inches.  July rainfall was near normal and brought some respite, but August saw just 1.21 inches of rain at Pellston.  A ban on burning was issued for most of the state in mid-August, the first such ban since 1998.  Golf courses and farmers complained of very high utility bills, due to the need for near-constant irrigation.  Corn and bean crops were severely impacted.  Rains in September would partially alleviate drought conditions for a spell.

Drought conditions (severe, D2) expanded into the tip of Northern Michigan by the end of August.  The was the result of a dry summer in the region.  The dryness dated as far back as May, when only 1.09 inches of rain fell in Pellston.  June rainfall was 1.92 inches.  July rainfall was near normal and brought some respite, but August saw just 1.21 inches of rain at Pellston.  A ban on burning was issued for most of the state in mid-August, the first such ban since 1998.  Golf courses and farmers complained of very high utility bills, due to the need for near-constant irrigation.  Corn and bean crops were severely impacted.  Rains in September would partially alleviate drought conditions for a spell.

Drought conditions (severe, D2) expanded eastward into Eastern Upper Michigan during August.  It was a dry summer in the region, especially in the Upper Peninsula.  Dryness started in late May, with just 0.30 inches of rain at Sault Ste Marie after May 16th through the end of the month.  June rainfall of 1.74 inches was 1.26 inches below normal.  Similarly, July rainfall at the Sault was 1.50 inches, 1.64 inches below normal.  August rainfall totalled 1.03 inches, a full 2.44 inches below normal.  The hay crop in Eastern Upper Michigan was 50 to 70 percent of normal.  The resulting lack of feed led some farmers to cut their cattle herds.  A burning ban was issued for the majority of the state in mid-August, the first such ban since 1998.  Significant rains in September would eventually alleviate the drought.

A cold front stalled out over the area and combined with an upper level low pressure system to support the development of severe thunderstorms. This event was very quick with the storms moving from Howell to just south of Detroit at 40 to 50 MPH. The most intense storm produced significant wind damage from southern Livingston County into northeast Washtenaw County. A tornado warning was issued for Washtenaw County. A National Weather Service field survey identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The storms knocked out power to 60 thousand customers in Southeast Lower Michigan. Half of downtown Brighton lost power, forcing numerous businesses to close. Several homes suffered damages from falling trees. There were no reports of any serious damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging wind and flash flooding over portions of south central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few roads closed in Gladstone due to flash flooding with nearly two inches of rain reported in less than two hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed over the region during the late afternoon hours of July 5th. There were numerous reports of large hail and damaging winds. The most intense winds occurred along a path stretching from just south of Saginaw to just north of Pontiac. These intense thunderstorm winds, gusting as high as 70 MPH, brought down many large trees. Remarkably, only a few homes sustained minor damages. There were also reports of large hail, some the size of ping pong balls. Numerous trees were also blown down across Livingston County, especially around the Fowlerville area. By sunset, the atmosphere became less capable of supporting severe thunderstorms and the event was over. No injuries were reported. At least 50 thousand customers lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fowlerville fire officials reported at least 10 trees down in the area, with one landing on a car at the intersection of Elliott and Mason Roads. The driver of the vehicle was taken to an area hospital with minor injuries. National Weather Service Meteorologists surveyed the damage and estimated straight line wind gusts up to 65 MPH.

There were also reports of large hail, some the size of ping pong balls. Numerous trees were also blown down across Livingston County, especially around the Fowlerville area. By sunset, the atmosphere became less capable of supporting severe thunderstorms and the event was over. No injuries were reported. At least 50 thousand customers lost power.

The most intense winds occurred along a path stretching from just south of Saginaw to just north of Pontiac. These intense thunderstorm winds, gusting as high as 70 MPH, brought down many large trees. Remarkably, only a few homes sustained minor damages. There were also reports of large hail, some the size of ping pong balls. Numerous trees were also blown down across Livingston County, especially around the Fowlerville area. By sunset, the atmosphere became less capable of supporting severe thunderstorms and the event was over. No injuries were reported. At least 50 thousand customers lost power.

A very unstable airmass coupled with a stalled out front was enough to fuel the development of two extremely intense thunderstorms. One of the storms managed to go from Mount Pleasant all the way to eastern Oakland County. The storm in Midland County became so intense that it prompted the issuance of a Tornado Warning. National Weather Service field surveys identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The Sanford area was hardest hit with many homes suffering damages from falling trees. Many local businesses in Sanford and Midland implemented tornado safety plans, moving customers to designated shelter areas. St Charles in Saginaw County was another area hit hard from downburst winds approaching 80 MPH. Total damages from the entire event approached nearly a quarter of a million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a house struck by lightning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass coupled with a stalled out front was enough to fuel the development of two extremely intense thunderstorms. One of the storms managed to go from Mount Pleasant all the way to eastern Oakland County. The storm in Midland County became so intense that it prompted the issuance of a Tornado Warning. National Weather Service field surveys identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The Sanford area was hardest hit with many homes suffering damages from falling trees. Many local businesses in Sanford and Midland implemented tornado safety plans, moving customers to designated shelter areas. St Charles in Saginaw County was another area hit hard from downburst winds approaching 80 MPH. Total damages from the entire event approached nearly a quarter of a million dollars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service field survey confirmed that straight line winds as high as 70 MPH blew down numerous large trees. At least 10 homes on Peterson Drive suffered damage from falling trees, some suffering heavy damage. Total damages to the homes were estimated at roughly $75K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled out over the area and combined with an upper level low pressure system to support the development of severe thunderstorms. This event was very quick with the storms moving from Howell to just south of Detroit at 40 to 50 MPH. The most intense storm produced significant wind damage from southern Livingston County into northeast Washtenaw County. A tornado warning was issued for Washtenaw County. A National Weather Service field survey identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The storms knocked out power to 60 thousand customers in Southeast Lower Michigan. Half of downtown Brighton lost power, forcing numerous businesses to close. Several homes suffered damages from falling trees. There were no reports of any serious damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service employee reported large tree branches down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported large trees down. The high winds also lifted and flipped a pontoon boat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass coupled with a stalled out front was enough to fuel the development of two extremely intense thunderstorms. One of the storms managed to go from Mount Pleasant all the way to eastern Oakland County. The storm in Midland County became so intense that it prompted the issuance of a Tornado Warning. This event will be remembered for the extreme intensity of large hail it generated. A most unusual hailstorm pounded areas in a 3 mile radius around the city of Durand. Severe hail fell for nearly an hour. At times, the hail was as big as golf balls. Hundreds of homes and vehicles suffered significant damages, totaling nearly 5 million dollars in this area alone. Large hail also caused significant damages to cars in and around the Adrian area. Mostly hail reports were received, but we did get a few wind damage reports from thunderstorm downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported quarter sized hail covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak, but persistent warm air advection moved into the region extending from eastern Iowa into northern Indiana. Extreme instability developed to the west across Illinois where CAPEs exceeded 5000 j/kg and LI's reached -10 C. As the instability advected east along this area of isentropic lift, thunderstorms rapidly developed. Due to the slow movement of these storms as well as precipitable water values at or above 2 inches, widepsread heavy rain was observed in many locations. With northwest flow aloft, the line drifted south and accelerated as a wave approached the area. While flooding ended up the main threat, embedded wind damage was observed in a few of the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in the southeast part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This event will be remembered for the extreme intensity of large hail it generated. A most unusual hailstorm pounded areas in a 3 mile radius around the city of Durand. This event will be remembered for the extreme intensity of large hail it generated. A most unusual hailstorm pounded areas in a 3 mile radius around the city of Durand. Severe hail fell for nearly an hour. At times, the hail was as big as golf balls. Hundreds of homes and vehicles suffered significant damages, totaling nearly 5 million dollars in this area alone. Large hail also caused significant damages to cars in and around the Adrian area. Mostly hail reports were received, but we did get a few wind damage reports from thunderstorm downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail hammered areas in a 3 mile radius around Durand for 50 minutes. The hail, at times, was as big as golf balls. A local newspaper reported $1.8M in hail damages to homes alone. Hundreds of vehicles also took a beating. Local experts estimated damages at an average of $4K per vehicle. This information was used to estimate $1M in total damages to vehicles. Many crops in the area were also destroyed. One farmer estimated $400K in  losses to soybeans alone. Total crop damages were estimated at a conservative $2M, bringing the total cost of this hailstorm to nearly $5M.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked from Lake Superior to James Bay. The associated strong cold front swept toward Lower Michigan on the late afternoon of July 10th. Southwesterly flow ahead of the front allowed a warm and moist unstable atmosphere to develop. Numerous pulse severe thunderstorms produced many reports of damaging wind gusts along and north of the I-69 corridor. There were no reports of hail. The most significant damage occurred in Fort Gratiot, where a strong thunderstorm downburst created straight line wind damage one mile wide covering two square miles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous trees and power poles down in Fort Gratiot, covering a 2 square mile area between Keewahdin and Carrigan Roads. Several homes received damage from falling trees. No one was injured. Total property damages were estimated at roughly $50K.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled out over the area and combined with an upper level low pressure system to support the development of severe thunderstorms. This event was very quick with the storms moving from Howell to just south of Detroit at 40 to 50 MPH. The most intense storm produced significant wind damage from southern Livingston County into northeast Washtenaw County. A tornado warning was issued for Washtenaw County. A National Weather Service field survey identified damages consistent with intense straight-line winds associated with thunderstorm downbursts. The storms knocked out power to 60 thousand customers in Southeast Lower Michigan. Half of downtown Brighton lost power, forcing numerous businesses to close. Several homes suffered damages from falling trees. There were no reports of any serious damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This event will be remembered for the extreme intensity of large hail it generated. A most unusual hailstorm pounded areas in a 3 mile radius around the city of Durand. Severe hail fell for nearly an hour. At times, the hail was as big as golf balls. Hundreds of homes and vehicles suffered significant damages, totaling nearly 5 million dollars in this area alone. Large hail also caused significant damages to cars in and around the Adrian area. Mostly hail reports were received, but we did get a few wind damage reports from thunderstorm downbursts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed on a very warm and moist Saturday afternoon. One area of severe storms moved through Shiawassee and northern Genesee Counties, producing wind damage and two reports of severe hail. Another area of storms formed farther to the south, leading to several reports of wind damage. There was also one report of a large tree down on a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a 60 MPH wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds over west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 7th.  A tornado also formed over Menominee County and uprooted numerous trees west of the town of Banat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 6:47 pm, a tornado touched down approximately 4 miles west of Banat in a forested area west of County Road 356. The EF-0 tornado was approximately 125 yards wide as it tore a quarter-mile path through forested areas and across County Road 356. With winds estimated at 80 mph, the tornado uprooted or snapped more than fifty large trees (diameter in excess of a foot and height greater than 50 feet) along its path before dissipating over forested swampland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous waves of thunderstorms affected southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening of June 27, 2007. Severe storms developed along and ahead of a cold front, which dropped south through a very warm and humid airmass. There were numerous reports of wind damage and hail. Saginaw County received two separate rounds of severe weather, producing hail to one-inch in diameter and a number of reports of trees and power poles blown down by winds. Flooding was also a concern, as some areas were repeatedly affected by complexes of storms. Northern Shiawassee County received the worst flooding, with National Weather Service radar estimating up to six inches of rainfall in just a few hours. A golfer in northwest Detroit was struck by lightning and killed after seeking refuge under a tree.

A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed on a very warm and moist Saturday afternoon. Another area of storms formed farther to the south, leading to several reports of wind damage. There was also one report of a large tree down on a home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported two trees down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local television stations reported a large tree down on a trailer home. Property damages were estimated at roughly $15K.

Scattered thunderstorms developed in advance of a strong cold front. A few of the storms became severe, having the biggest impact across Wayne County. Wind gusts as high as 65 MPH blew down several trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local television stations reported trees and power lines down in northwest Detroit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front continued to creep across the region on the 9th.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along the front in the afternoon, producing severe weather in the Saginaw Bay region.  This included the first tornado of the year in Northern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed between Gladwin and Beaverton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front continued to creep across the region on the 9th.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along the front in the afternoon, producing severe weather in the Saginaw Bay region.  This included the first tornado of the year in Northern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly crawled south through the lower peninsula of Michigan. Plenty of sunshine broke out over the Tri-Cities and sent temperatures to near 90 degrees. The atmosphere became unstable and the stage was set for severe thunderstorms to develop. Thunderstorms developed shortly after noon and were intense, but short-lived. A few storms along the cold front showed some rotation and tornado warnings were issued for Tuscola and Sanilac counties. No tornadoes were reported. The event only lasted a couple of hours and the last warning was canceled shortly after 1600 EST as the northernmost storms moved out over Lake Huron, and the southernmost storms weakened rather rapidly. Most of the events with this episode were marginally severe with one solid severe event in northern Bay County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported large tree branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An historic tornado outbreak rocked Northern Lower Michigan on the afternoon and evening of October 18th.  The day started out cool and rainy, but a dry slot aloft allowed sunshine to break out in the afternoon.  Temperatures rose into the lower to middle 70s in parts of the area.  The warm and humid air was unstable enough to fuel multiple rounds of thunderstorms in the late afternoon and evening hours.  There was a tremendous amount of shear in the atmosphere, and many storms quickly became supercells with rotating updrafts.  This was an environment conducive to tornadoes, as several lines of discrete supercells crossed Northern Lower Michigan.||Northern Lower Michigan had a record six tornadoes on the day.  The previous high was five, set on June 17 1992.  Unfortunately, the Kalkaska tornado produced a fatality.  That was the first tornado fatality in Northern Lower Michigan since March 30 1976, when a single death occurred in Ogemaw County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail near the intersection of US-127 and County Road 104.

The previous high was five, set on June 17 1992.  Unfortunately, the Kalkaska tornado produced a fatality.  That was the first tornado fatality in Northern Lower Michigan since March 30 1976, when a single death occurred in Ogemaw County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds caused sporadic tree damage in southeast Alpena County.  Minor damage to mobile homes occurred near Shawlani Road.
